RFO::AccessModeAccess modeMode of access to shared data. Using binary representation [bit3 | bit2 | bit1 | bit0], bit1 is set iff mode is a concurrent mode (r or cw) bit3 is set iff mode is a postponed, other bits are used for identification

RFO::BaseClosureA closure object is a call to a function. It is also called task.The closure is created to represent a computation. Using closure the users may split its works into subcomputation called closures. A closure has a runtime state that is inherited from Core::Condition which allows to defined five states, INIT, EXEC, STEAL, WAIT, and TERM. The state diagram is the following. Note that the state EXEC also represents closures that are ready and, at the end, terminated

RFO::ClosureA closure object is a call to a function. It is also called task.Closure of type Closure is based closure that can be pushed into Frame container. BaseClosure for the purpose of closure object
RFO::ClosureAttributType of attribut for a closureThis type allows to code attribut for a closure on an 32 bits unsigned integer. Default attributs are stored from bit 0 to bit 2 :

  • bit0 is the stealable attribut which equals to 1 iff the closure could not be theft
  • bit1 is the uniqueness attribut which equals to 1 iff the closure execution should be unique [Not implemented]
  • bit2 is the local attribut which equals to 1 iff the closure should be steal only by local thread
  • bit3 is the site attribut which equals to 1 iff the closure has a site constraint
  • bit4 is the ocr attribut which equals to 1 iff the closure has an ocr mapping constraint The attribut may be extended by users: The representation is on 32 bits unsigned integer
RFO::ClosureFormatFormat for a closureDescribe for each C++ type of closure the format of all associated objects

WS::CommunityCommunity of distribued PoolsThe community is a dynamic group of process. The Community object is responsible to implement the distributed workstealing using active message of the network. The object is responsible to implement default method for Callback and Upcall method in order to defined the behaviors in case of errors. The Community is an Object (from Net::Group and Core::WorkSet inheritences) with an identifier generated by the Net::Group object
FT::CommunityObjectCommunityObjectClass of objects that request reference to a community object
Util::Event::compare
Core::ConditionCondition to signal end of steal operationThis class implements one method for synchronisation between a thief and its victim. When a thief thread has successed to steal work from a victim thread, a condition object may be used to express the synchronization of waiting the end of the execution of all theft works. The condition object may be used to wait multiple thiefs before the victim continue
Util::ConditionPosix conditionsThis class implements interface to posix condition variable. All errors are returned by throwing exception

SOCKNET::ConnexionDefinition of objects with possibility of waiting to select events due to network actibity A connexion object represents a socket with a access state. Such object allows to select them from a set in order to deals with communication events. See also the Selector class. A Connexion object has a name (an integer) and a state (connected, disconnected, under connection). The class does not provide method to establish connexion. It should be defined into derived class. A connexion could be attached to a Selector, see above

Util::CounterManagerManagement of counters to collect in order to produce statisticsEach process generates an Counters data that correspond to a set of counters (user defined, applications defined...). These Counters are cumulated in order to produce global statistics about the execution. This operation involves an field by field accumulation with various cumulative operators (+, max, min ). A set of userdefined field exist. That could be re-used in order to cumulate order counter
Util::CountersCounters generate by each gid and accumulated on the collector processSuch object contains a static set of interger and floating point value counters. Each counter should be interpreted with respect to the CounterManager::manager that stores the information about the type of counter and the way two values may be merge
Stat::StatisticsService::CountersDescription
Util::CpuTimerCPU timer class
Util::CriticalGuardTransparent mutual exclusion facility.This class implements a transparent local scoping usage of mutex lock. An instance of this class is used to lock a bloc expression using the lexical scope of variable definition in C++. At the initialization of such an object, the associated mutex is locked and is unlocked at the destruction of the object (at the end of its scope as a C++ variable). Note that the unlock method is alway called even if an exception is thrown. Please read the code example associated with the Mutex class before reading this code

Util::FormatOperationCumul
RFO::FrameFrame is a list of ordered closure.The frame correspond to an activation frame associated to each evaluation of closure, i.e. a call to function. A frame stores the list of created closures using the order of creation. Each newly created closure is added into the back side of the list, while they are consumed in the front side (FIFO queue). Frames are order into a stack
Sched::GenericFactoryOptimizer< T >
Sched::GenericFactoryScheduler< T >
DFG::GlobalDataA GlobalData is a reference to a data into the distributed memory
DFG::GlobalDataAttributType of attribut for a versionThis type allows to code attribut for a global data on an 32 bits unsigned integer. The following bits are reserved:

  • _attr & 0x1 == 1 iff the global data is in a stack, else it is in heap
  • _attr & 0x2 == 1 iff the data is sticky and could not be moved, neither destroyed or copied
DFG::GlobalDataFormatFormat of a GlobalData
Util::GlobalIdClass for representing a global identifier of the distributed processusGlobal Identifier values are segmented in order to reserve special name for some special meaning. The unsigned integer on 32 bits are organized as following: b31|b30|...|b1|b0 where bi is the i-th bit. b31 is the high order bit. Bits b31|b30, if non nul represent special values.

  • b31|b30 = 0|0: user defined values between 0 and 2^30-1 (1073741823 values)
  • b31|b30|b29= 1|1|1: special values
    • ALL_SITE: all other bits are =1
    • NO_SITE: all other bits are =0
  • b31|b30|b29= 1|1|0: for identifying checkpoint servers
  • b31|b30|b29= 1|0|0: for identifying temporary name using counter
  • b31|b30|b29= 1|0|1: for identifying temporary name using hash value
Net::GlobalPointerGlobalPointer is a pointer on data on a remote processThis class allows to mask heterogeneous representation of pointer (32/64bits) and is an opaque representation of a pointer of a remote process. Only the remote process may do indirection of the pointer
Util::GlobalPointerGlobalPointer is a pointer on data on a remote processThis class allows to mask heterogeneous representation of pointer (32/64bits) and is an opaque representation of a pointer of a remote process. Only the remote process may do indirection of the pointer
NetData::GlobalVariableGlobalVariable reference a global variable visible from all process. The semantic of update on write and update on read could be parametrized. Update may be propagate on each new computed value or after a fixed period of time. The same may be defined while a process is reading a variable

heapitem
FT::HeartBeatDetectorHeartbeat fault tolerance detectorThe algorithm is to send to randomly selected known local node a message at a certain period and to test is a reply was arrived before a certain latency. If not the node is marked as suspected and then marked as failed. In this case, the node is signaled to the kaapicontroller. The HeartBeat detector is controlled by following properties

  • 'ft.fdetector.heartbeat.period' <integer> : the period of heart beat
  • 'ft.fdetector.heartbeat.latency' <integer> : the latency before a node is considered as suspect

FT::LoadCheckpointServiceCheckpoint service to load checkpoint fileThe FT::LoadCheckpointService::service expose both client and server interface to load checkpoint file from the Store service. In order to load a checkpoint file, the implementation re-play the stored message (the checkpoint file) with new destination (the node that requires the checkpoint file) and new service identifier (the LoadCheckpointService::service)
FT::LocalCheckpointControllerLocal process controler attached to any running process under the control of a FT protocolSuch a class should extended by a specific FT protocol in order to implement the local part of the control required by a FT protocol. By default method of this class allows to stop all running threads in a checkpointable state and take a snapshot of the process by checkpointing each stopped threads. The role of derivation is to attach the object to a community name in order that theses methods checkpoint the right community

During the distribution or redistribution process, some events may be generated on receiving data or sending data. A collection and a localcollection are associated by sharing the same name (identifier)

Util::ObjectObject with synchronisation mutex and condition variablesThe Object class defines object that needs to have and identifier, reference counter and synchronisation primitives. Only the identifier and reference counter are part of the state of the object. The synchronisation objects (one mutex and one condition) should not considered as in the state of the object. Thus all methods involving only synchronisation objects may be declared as 'const' with respect to the object

Core::ProcessorKAAPI ProcessorProcessor manages scheduling of a set of threads with at most one active thread at any time. Util::RuntimeError
Util::RWCriticalGuardTransparent mutual exclusion facility.This class implements a transparent local scoping usage of RW lock. An instance of this class is used to read-lock a bloc expression using the lexical scope of variable definition in C++. At the initialization of such an object, the associated rwlock is read-locked and is unlocked at the destruction of the object (at the end of its scope as a C++ variable). Note that the unlock method is alway called even if an exception is thrown. Please read the code example associated with the RWLock class before reading this code
Util::RWLockRead-Write lockThis class implements interface for Posix Read-Write lock. All errors are reported to by throwing an exception with error code contained into the error code of the exception, see Exception

Util::StatisticCompute some statistics about series of valuesThis class acts like as a stream on which series of values may be inserted. The object computes basic statistics (count,total,average,standard deviation, min, max) of a series of double floating point values

Core::StealableBase interface for object that accepts steal request
Core::StealableWithInstanceReificationInterface for object that accepts steal request with instance reificationInstances of class that inherits from StealableWithInstanceReification can reify the steal method by providing a object that implements StealAlgorithm using an invocation of reify method
Core::StealAlgorithmBase class to implement an algorithm for work stealingAll objects that inherit from Stealable class are able to reify the method invocation steal in order to specify a given algorithm object of class StealAlgorithm
Sched::stiCompilerGroups some specific method to manipulate DFG and generate thread ready for executionThis class defined methods that allows to schedule a DFG on N ressources and generate code of thread for each ressource. This process is resumed in the next figure: 1/ the state of execution of a running thread is captured in order to access to its KAAPI' stack of execution; 2/ The KAAPI's stack is a DFG which is scheduled and, at the end the code for each thread is generated (the description of this process is given above); 3/ The execution of each thread generated by previous steps may be input for an other scheduling process
FT::StoreCheckpointServiceCheckpoint service to store fileOn each process of a Kaapi application, a checkpoint service accepts request from remote node in order to store checkpoint data. Each process has its checkpoint server where it will store its checkpoint data. The default service is FT::StoreCheckpointService::service. The class definition expose both client and server interface.The server side store directly the incomming message that correspond to the serialization of a thread (thus, if the library is compiled with heterogeneous support, the message could be reload from any process). To load checkpoint files that correspond to threads, the FT::LoadCheckpointService::service object should be used

DFG::ThreadFlow of control with data flow graph representationThe DFG threads inherits from the the RFO threads the structure of stack of frames of closures to implement the reference order of execution of closures. Once a DFG thread is started, it execute all its closures with respect to this order. If a closure is in state WAITING (for a non data flow constraint), the thread is suspended as a RFO thread
RFO::ThreadFlow of control with data flow graph representationThe RFO::Thread represents computation (work) as a list of Task managed by the Reference Order for Athapascan1. Tasks are assumed to be independent: stealing a RFO::Thread will returned, if exists, the last recent task of the stack following the reference order of execution
Util::ThreadPOSIX interface to thread
Core::ThreadFlow of controlA Core::Thread is a flow of control which consist of its runtime environnement (data, registers ...). This is the basic unit to execute part of the program. Multiple thread may be running at the same time, and its depends on the concrete implementation of the class. A Core::Thread is also and Core::WorkSet with its own synchronisation object inherited from Util::Mutex. The difference between a WorkSet and a Thread is that Thread has no childs (workset). A Thread inherits from Util::Thread the fact that it is a flow of control may be concurrent with other Util::Thread or Core::Thread. A current running thread of control, for instance the main thread of a process, may be attached as a Core::Thread by calling the method Thread::attach_host_thread(). Each created thread on a node with a globalid has an Util::Object::identifier of the form ((gid << 16)|local_counter)
Sched::ThreadFlow of control with data flow graph representation

Sched::ThreadGroupLocal view of Group of Sched::ThreadSuch object exists on each site where a ThreadGroup has been dispatched. It represents some part of the thread group (local thread) as well as other global informations about the other threads. This is not a user interface

Core::WakeupFirstProcessorStealAlgorithmDefaultStealAlgorithm of a K-Processor1/ if local steal then try to wakeup thread 2/ if thief_processor is the attached processor then steal an victim processor 3/ steal task in suspended thread 4/ steal task in active thread 5/ steal on the workset
Util::WallTimerWall clock timer class
Core::WorkSetWorkSet of worksetThe workset is a set of processors with a steal interface to steal work from the set of processors. The workset is formed by attaching processors. The default workset is created using the factory WorkSetFactory. The default number of processors are created using the ProcessorFactory. Both factory are defined in Core::Init class
Core::WorkSetFactoryComponent for initialization of the default workset
Core::WorkSetStealAlgorithmStealAlgorithm on a worksetThis is the base class for stealing over a workset. By default, no instance of this class is attached to the workset, and a workset could not be stolen (invocation to steal always return false)
